Situation1: They interact warmly with a long line of shoppers during a busy lunch hour.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: During a street demonstration, someone urges them to step past a barricade onto restricted city property.
Story:
The lunch rush at the store is always a test of patience, but today, I’m determined to greet every customer with a smile, even as the line snakes out the door. My manager expects me to keep things moving and make everyone feel welcome, so I chat with the regulars and offer a kind word to the tired parents juggling groceries and toddlers. Just as I finish ringing up a customer, I glance outside and see a crowd gathering—today’s the day of the big demonstration downtown. I remember my civic duty: respect the law, protect public spaces, and not get swept up in chaos.

But as my shift ends, I step outside and find myself in the thick of the protest. Someone I recognize from the neighborhood grabs my arm, urging me to cross the barricade with them, insisting it’s the only way to make our voices heard. I hesitate, torn. As a cashier, I’m supposed to be friendly, approachable, and part of the community. As a citizen, I know the rules are there for a reason. My heart pounds as I stand at the edge, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which expectation I should honor.
